title: Advanced Beauty Lighting Deconstruction with 6 Lights
summary: Lindsay Adler demonstrates a complex creative lighting setup for a beauty portrait, utilizing six strobes, gels, and optical spots to sculpt light and enhance gemstone textures.

steps.action: Set up the Main Light using an Optical Spot with a 150mm lens to create a precise, dappled pocket of hard light on the face.
Add a Fill Light using a bare strobe with a Cyan gel to fill shadows with blue color while maintaining hard specular highlights.
Set up the Background Light using a bare strobe with a Magenta gel on a Coral background to create a saturated pink gradient.
steps.tool: Profoto D2, Magenta Gel, Savage Universal Coral Background

steps.action: Add the first Hair Light using an Optical Spot focused specifically on the hair to create highlights on the gemstones.
Add a Rim Light using a bare strobe with a Cyan gel to create a blue wash on the back left side of the hair.
Add a second Hair Light using an Optical Spot with a Pink gel for subtle highlights on the right side.
steps.tool: Profoto D2, Optical Spot, Pink Gel

steps.action: Configure camera settings: Canon R5 with 70-200mm lens at f/11 for sharpness and depth of field.
Attach a Tiffen North Star filter to the lens to create multi-point starburst reflections on the gemstones.
Process the RAW file by adding significant contrast and clarity to counteract the haze from the star filter, and adjusting color balance (Cyan to highlights, Magenta to shadows).
Retouch the image by cleaning up skin, filling hair gaps, and painting a pink layer set to 'Color' blend mode to change the hair color.

key_takeaways: Use hard light modifiers like optical spots and bare bulbs to create specular highlights on reflective subjects like gemstones.
Start with a standard lighting configuration (Main, Fill, Background, Rims) and modify individual lights to suit the creative vision.
Star filters create beautiful in-camera effects but introduce haze that requires adding contrast and clarity in post-processing.
Optical spots allow for precise control to highlight specific areas without affecting the rest of the image.
